title: analysis
text:
With this chunk of code we load the packages needed for the analysis.

library(babynames)
library(knitr)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyr)
library(pheatmap)

Load the custom functions. Use the #| code-fold: true to hide the code


Code
#
get_most_frequent <- function(babynames, select_sex, from = 1950) {
  most_freq <- babynames |>
    filter(sex == select_sex, year > from) |>
    group_by(name) |>
    summarise(average = mean(prop)) |>
    arrange(desc(average))
    
  return(list(
    babynames = babynames,
    most_frequent = most_freq,
    sex = select_sex,
    from = from))
}

plot_top <- function(x, top = 10) {
  topx <- x$most_frequent$name[1:top]
  
  p <- x$babynames |>
    filter(name %in% topx, sex == x$sex, year > x$from) |>
    ggplot(aes(x = year, y = prop, color = name)) +
    geom_line() +
    scale_color_brewer(palette = "Paired") +
    theme_classic()
  
  return(p)
}





In this chunk of code we print the head of the table

head(babynames)

# A tibble: 6 × 5
   year sex   name          n   prop
  <dbl> <chr> <chr>     <int>  <dbl>
1  1880 F     Mary       7065 0.0724
2  1880 F     Anna       2604 0.0267
3  1880 F     Emma       2003 0.0205
4  1880 F     Elizabeth  1939 0.0199
5  1880 F     Minnie     1746 0.0179
6  1880 F     Margaret   1578 0.0162


Here we also render the table

head(babynames) |> kable()

Try to access a file outside the main directory

dir("../test/scr/")

character(0)





Plotting them for girls like this:

get_most_frequent(babynames, select_sex = "F") |> plot_top()







Figure 1: Line plot displaying proportion of top 10 girl names by year





Plotting them for boys like this:

get_most_frequent(babynames, select_sex = "M") |> plot_top()




Line plot displaying proportion of top 10 boy names by year





# get most frequent girl names from 2010 onwards
from_year <- 2010
most_freq_girls <- get_most_frequent(babynames, select_sex = "F",
                                     from = from_year)

# plot top 5 girl names
most_freq_girls |>
  plot_top(top = 5)

# plot top 10 girl names
most_freq_girls |>
  plot_top(top = 10)

# get top 30 girl names in a matrix
# with names in rows and years in columns
prop_df <- babynames |> 
  filter(name %in% most_freq_girls$most_frequent$name[1:30] & sex == "F") |>
  filter(year >= from_year) |> 
  select(year, name, prop) |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = year,
              values_from = prop)

prop_mat <- as.matrix(prop_df[, 2:ncol(prop_df)])
rownames(prop_mat) <- prop_df$name

# create heatmap
pheatmap(prop_mat, cluster_cols = FALSE, scale = "row")











(a) Plot top 5











(b) Plot top 10













(c) Plot heatmap top 30







Figure 2: Plots




In Figure 2 (a) and Figure 2 (b) the line plots are shown. To view trends of many names at once, Figure 2 (c) displays a heatmap.
Add a new line to see the live command

babynames %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  summarise(n = n())

# A tibble: 138 × 2
    year     n
   <dbl> <int>
 1  1880  2000
 2  1881  1935
 3  1882  2127
 4  1883  2084
 5  1884  2297
 6  1885  2294
 7  1886  2392
 8  1887  2373
 9  1888  2651
10  1889  2590
# ℹ 128 more rows

title: Interactive work without a server with web assembly
tutorial
text:
DOI



Introduction
In this project we aim to visualize the trends of the most frequently used babynames from 1880 to 2017 in the United States. We do this by:

Understanding the different columns of the data set
Find the top 10 most frequently used baby names in the data for:

girls
boys

Plot the yearly trend of the top 10 baby names




baby_image

title: Interactive work without a server with web assembly
text:
A more complex examples with more interactive inputs (NB: it seems that when moving the slider the image get re-computed for each intermediate value, leading to some slowness sometimes) :









viewof sex_show = Inputs.radio(["M", "F"], {label: "Sex:",value:"F"})

viewof year = Inputs.range([1880, 2010], {step: 10, label: "starting year:"})

viewof n_names = Inputs.range([1, 12], {step: 1, label: "number of top names:"})






















You can also just have interactive R/python cells where you can write and execute code :
